newsitem.title: FRANCE: French capital markets closing report.
newsitem.headline: French capital markets closing report.

text.p: Ten-year bond futures settled higher on Friday, shrugging off an opinion poll released on Thursday suggesting that the opposition Socialists were closing in on the ruling centre-right coalition in the French parliamentary race.
"Despite everything, the market still believes the right will end up winning," said one trader at a French brokerage.

Analysts said that the 10-year bond future could press higher at the start of the week, with an initial upside target for 130.0. Volume was a thin 40,787 contracts traded as many traders took the day off after Thursday's public holiday.
The 10-year bond future traded in a small 20-point range, settling off its best levels. June PIBOR finished unchanged. The 10-year OAT-bund spread was steady at minus nine.

Some analysts were surprised at the lack of reaction to the IPSOS poll on Thursday showing that the rightist RPR/UDF coalition would get 290 seats in the National Assembly, just one more than is needed for a majority, the Socialists and their allies would win 264 and the Communists 22 for a total of 286, four short of the RPR-UDF tally.
"It's quite amazing that the market didn't react to the poll," said one analyst.
"The market assumes, probably rightly, that even if the Socialists win, they will remain committed to monetary union," said Jean-Francois Mercier of Salomon Brothers.

A win by the Socialists would trigger an initial big sell-off, economists reckon, but they predict the market would stabilise after it became clear that Socialist policy would not deviate much from that of the centre-right.

If opinion polls show no further erosion of the right's lead, the main focus next week would be a raft of U.S. data which will be the final batch before the U.S. FOMC meets on May 20, one analyst said.
The U.S. data includes retail sales on Tuesday, producer prices on Wednesday, and jobless claims and consumer prices on Thursday.
Analysts said although there was not much price movement in PIBOR, investors were returning to the three-month interest rate future and there were a number a number of open positions.
"The reaction could be pretty violent either way depending on how the things (the election) turns out," said one dealer.
The two-round election takes place on May 25 and June 1.
"Overall people are pretty positive, they just don't seem to believe in a win by the left -- and also the market is being helped by a very supportive international market," said a trader.
"There just are not too many sellers about, people don't take the risk of selling," said another.
The franc firmed slightly to 3.3729 per mark at the end of the day, up from 3.3740 on Thursday.
